message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of left-sided scrotal pain with nausea and vomiting, pain during urination, and a tender, swollen left testicle with an erythematous left hemiscrotum suggests acute epididymitis or orchitis. Scrotal ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not necessary unless there are other signs or symptoms suggestive of metastatic disease. Surgical exploration may be necessary in rare cases of testicular torsion or abscess. Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer is not necessary in this case as the patient's symptoms are not consistent with a mumps infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest epididymitis. Scrotal ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step in management. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not necessary at this point. Surgical exploration is not indicated without further diagnostic testing. Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer is not needed for this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including left-sided scrotal pain, swollen testicle, and leukocyte esterase and WBCs in urine, suggest epididymitis or orchitis. Scrotal ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm the diagnosis and rule out torsion, which will require immediate surgical exploration. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis and measurement of serum mumps IgG titer are not useful in the diagnosis of epididymitis or orchitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest epididymoorchitis or testicular torsion. Scrotal ultrasonography is the next step to distinguish between the two and determine the best course of treatment. CT scan and mumps IgG titer are not relevant to the situation, and surgical exploration can be considered as a last resort.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam suggest the presence of epididymitis or orchitis. Scrotal ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm the diagnosis and determine the degree of involvement. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not necessary at this stage. Surgical exploration is not indicated unless there is suspicion of testicular torsion, which is not suggested by the history or exam findings. Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer is not indicated as there is no suggestive history or physical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination are consistent with epididymitis or testicular torsion, but prevalence of testicular torsion is quite low in sexually active men. Scrotal ultrasonography is necessary to make a definitive diagnosis and distinguish between the two. Other options are not appropriate for this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest testicular torsion or epididymitis. Scrotal ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step in management to distinguish between the two conditions. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, surgical exploration, and measurement of serum mumps IgG titer are not necessary at this point.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's clinical presentation of tender, swollen left testicle and erythematous left hemiscrotum, along with leukocyte esterase on urine dipstick and WBCs in urinalysis suggest epididymitis. Scrotal ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step in management to evaluate for epididymitis and rule out other conditions such as testicular torsion or malignancy. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not necessary for the diagnosis of epididymitis. Surgical exploration would be necessary if the patient had testicular torsion, which is less likely given the gradual onset of symptoms. Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer is not necessary as mumps is not a likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including scrotal pain, nausea, and leukocyte esterase in the urine, suggest possible epididymitis or testicular torsion. Scrotal ultrasonography can help differentiate between the two conditions and is the most appropriate next step in management. CT scan and surgical exploration are not necessary at this stage. Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer is not indicated as there is no indication of mumps infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest acute epididymitis, which can be confirmed with scrotal ultrasonography. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not necessary at this point. Surgical exploration is not indicated unless there is concern for testicular torsion. Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer is not relevant in this case as the patient’s symptoms are not consistent with mumps infection.
